â€œIn a similar way now, create a function that takes a list of artist names and return their 50 first appearances as a dictionaryâ€

but am i doing the function wrong? should it convert to a dataframe within the function itself? :see_no_evil:

```

def fave_artists(artist):
    for artist in artists:
        my_artists.append(sp.search(q={artist}, limit=10))
    return my_artists```
then refer to the list above, not putting a single artist in (e.g. `'fave _artists("prince")` )

```fave_artists(artists)```

text:
A question:
I want to zip 2 lists into a dict. However in my dict I only get 1 value pair. When i zip the 2 lists into a new list, I get all the entries.
How do I get all the value pairs in my dict?

elements.text:
A question:
I want to zip 2 lists into a dict. However in my dict I only get 1 value pair. When i zip the 2 lists into a new list, I get all the entries.
How do I get all the value pairs in my dict?

text: but wait the issue there is that your keys are not unique, you have to flip them around

elements.text: but wait the issue there is that your keys are not unique, you have to flip them around

text: so spotify should be the value and the id is the key

elements.text: so spotify should be the value and the id is the key

text: you are getting a 1 key dictionary because dictionaries only allow unique keys, and you only have one there: spotify

elements.text: you are getting a 1 key dictionary because dictionaries only allow unique keys, and you only have one there: spotify
